title: Rumour Mill: Messi decision world’s been waiting on
text:
Rumour Mill: Messi to stay at Barca, PSG stars attracting PL interest, Ozil not impacted by Wenger March 13, 2017 3:42pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS LIONEL Messi decides his club future, why Mesut Ozil’s Arsenal exit doesn’t depend on Arsene Wenger, and Antonio Conte demands a $320 million war chest. 
All that and more in Monday Rumour Mill! 
MESSI DECIDES CLUB FUTURE: REPORT 
Lionel Messi wants to commit his future to Barcelona, according to Spanish newspaper Mundo Deportivo. 
The Argentine’s father and agent Jorge has reportedly told Barca club president Josep Maria Bartomeu that Messi is prepared to sign a new contract worth around $56 million each year (or £670,000-a-week). His current deal is set to expire in June 2018.. 
Barca have recently given new contracts to Neymar, Sergio Busquets and Javier Mascherano, but the club haven’t been able to reach an agreement with Messi. 
After the win over PSG, Neymar said: “Leo will renew. That is for sure.” 
But the Champions League victory hasn’t changed coach Luis Enrique’s mind about leaving the Catalan giant at the end of the season. 
He said: “Nothing has changed [regarding my future]. It would be a bit daft to change something based on what happens in 90 minutes… or 95.” Deportivo La Coruna's midfielder Alex Bergantinos (L) vies with Barcelona's Argentinian forward Lionel Messi. Source: AFP 
PREMIER LEAGUE LINES UP FOR PSG FLOPS 
After the disappointing result for PSG, French TV show Telefoot had a look at how their squad could change in the summer. 
The report said Adrien Rabiot is attracting interest from Arsenal, Tottenham and AC Milan, Edinson Cavani is being looked at by Chelsea, Atletico Madrid and Juventus, while Marquinhos is an option for Chelsea, Manchester United or Barcelona. 
Marco Verratti was linked with Barcelona and Bayern Munich, while Angel Di Maria and Blaise Matuidi are reportedly attracting interest from Chinese Super League clubs. Paris Saint-Germain's Argentinian forward Angel Di Maria (R). Source: AFP 
OZIL: MY FUTURE NOT DEPENDENT ON WENGER 
Mesut Ozil and Alexis Sanchez want a wage to match Paul Pogba’s £290,000-a-week salary at Manchester United to stay at Arsenal, according to the London Evening Standard , but the German says his future does not depend on whether Arsene Wenger stays at the club. 
“I have always said I’m very happy at Arsenal,” he told Bild. 
“Everything fits here - the club, the fans and the city. Arsene Wenger was also one of the main reasons why I joined Arsenal. 
“However, I also know that in football everything moves very quickly and a lot differently to what you had planned. Therefore, it would be wrong to say that my future is dependent on the coach. 
“Everything is still open. There have been talks with Arsenal but at the moment, I’m concentrating on the current season, just like the officials at Arsenal.” 
Ozil is currently the club’s highest-paid player on £140,000 a week, while Sanchez takes home £10,000 less. Mesut Ozil. Source: Getty Images 
VIEIRA: WENGER WILL STAY AND FIGHT 
Arsenal legends Patrick Vieira and Ian Wright believes Wenger will sign a new deal with the Gunners. 
However, Vieira also believes that his players should bare the blame for their underwhelming campaign so far. 
“I know Arsene and he is not the type of person to throw in the towel and just walk out of this situation,” said the New York City coach. 
“He will fight for it because he is proud and he will give everything like he has been doing for the football club. 
“It is true people have been putting a lot of doubt on Arsene’s capability of coaching the team and managing the team but when you get to some situations you have to look at the players. 
“I think some of the players have been letting Arsene down a lot... when they are on the field the players have to fight, to jump, to compete and if you don’t do it then it is your problem.” Arsenal's French striker Olivier Giroud (C) shakes hands with Arsene Wenger. Source: AFP 
Wright believes Wenger will be presented with a new two-year deal as owner Stan Kroenke is more concerned with Arsenal’s revenues than the amount of trophies they’ve won. 
Wright told BT Sport: “We found out there’s a two-year contract on the table a month or two months ago. 
“He always sees his contracts out and signs a new one and I can’t see what will be different this time. 
“Why would Kroenke sack a person who can double his money? 
“It doesn’t seem like they’re worried about if Wenger wins the Champions League as long as he qualifies… if he wins the league as long as he’s in the top four.” Anti-Wenger 'Wexit' protest 0:23 
A RSENAL STRIKER BLOWS 
New striker Lucas Perez is ready to quit the club after struggling to break into the first-team, according to Goal. 
The 29-year-old has impressed in the limited performances he’s made, but reportedly wants to move clubs to press his claim for a spot in Spain’s 2018 World Cup squad. 
This comes as former Gunners target Alexandre Lacazette is attracting interest from Atletico Madrid, according to Marca. 
The 25-year-old has long been tipped for a move away from Lyon, but the Spanish club could face competition from Liverpool and Juventus, who have also been linked with the forward. Lyon's Goal of the Year entry 0:32 
However, the Reds may be more concerned with securing the signature of Fulham 16-year-old sensation Ryan Sessegnon with the club confident of signing him for £10m, according to The Sun. 
Meanwhile, Jack Wilshere says he has no idea if he will be at Arsenal or Bournemouth (where he’s on loan) next season, according to The Mail. 
The 25-year-old midfielder said: “I’m not thinking about it.” 
“I’ve got a year left at Arsenal. As soon as the season ends, I’l sit down and I’ll think about it. 
“But my main concern at the moment is trying to keep Bournemouth in this league. 
“No matter what happens next year – if I’m here, if I’m not, if I’m at Arsenal, whatever – you know no-one wants a relegation next to their name. 
“You don’t want to be involved in a team that got relegated so that’s what we’ re doing now, trying to put Bournemouth in a good position. 
“At the end of the season I’ll have a think about it.” West Bromwich Albion's Jake Livermore, left, and AFC Bournemouth's Jack Wilshere battle for the ball. Source: AP 
CONTE WANTS $320 MILLION WARCHEST 
Arsenal will face competition from Chelsea to sign Wolverhampton Wanderers’ £20m-rated winger Helder Costa , according to The Sun , but the Blues could blow the Gunners out of the water if Antonio Conte gets his way. 
The manager has demanded £200 million ($320m) to spend on transfers in the summer in his bid to take Chelsea to the summit of European football, according to The Times. 
Some of those funds would reportedly be used to tie down Diego Costa and Thibaut Courtois , who have been linked with moves back to La Liga. Chelsea's Italian head coach Antonio Conte. Source: AFP 
KOEMAN HOPING LUKAKU SIGNS NEW DEAL 
Ronaldo Koeman is hoping Romelu Lukaku signs a new Everton deal following his 19th Premier League goal of the season against West Brom. 
“It’s still close to being signed - maybe I need to sign that contract then we can finish with all the stories,” Koeman said. 
“What we like is that strikers find the best position at the time in the game and normally that is around the box. 
“But sometimes if you drop to the left or right that makes space for other players and that was the message before the game: we need running players.” Overnight EPL wrap 0:56 
VILLA TO STAY IN NEW YORK, PIRLO UNSURE 
New York City manager Patrick Vieira confirmed David Villa is keen to stay with the MLS club while Andrea Pirlo could depart. 
Villa and Pirlo’s contracts expire after this season, but the Italian midfielder hasn’t considered what’s next. 
“I think David wants to sign; we want to keep him. It’s easy,” NYCFC manager Patrick Vieira said. New York City FC players Andrea Pirlo (L) and David Villa. Source: AFP 
“We don’t want him to go anywhere — we want him to stay, the family is really happy. All the parts want to work together. It’s just a question of time and to see what is going to happen. Leave the time to the time.” 
“I don’t know if it will be my last season. Now I think about playing and playing well for the club. When it will be the time, I’ll decide the future,” Pirlo said. 
“I don’t know. I think to play now. After I don’t know what will be my future. It’s important to play well. After this season, I decide if I continue to play or come back to Italy to retire.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
